title: Thursday, 25th October 2018
bodyHTML:
11:07 am

Hello! Welcome, hi there, good morning. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's noise-to-signal generator.

Grouchmonkey Bonjour
Manxish Good Morning

Let's check in on how this market rout's going.

Viking1 Forester , Yep to put it mildly I guess you could make it into a hotel

And advertising companies can't adjust their costs quickly the later in the year it gets, which is why margins take a hit.

11:20 am

So. 2018 comes back 10% or so. 2019 .... who knows?

BE11:20am

Here's Citi.

BE11:20am

The company were refreshingly, but disappointingly, clear that this is WPP specific rather than driven by macro trends or fundamental pressures on the industry. That is helpful in that it signals the rebound in performance at peers is not a ‘head fake’ but it is unhelpful in that it signals the turnaround at WPP could well take some time. In terms of the key actions, it is clear that more ‘investment’ is required which will drag on margins. More importantly, it strikes us that more combinations (along the line of VML/Y&R) will be needed.

Sails Debenhams bought Magasin du Nord in Denmark for £12.3m in 2009, according to the Independent
Forester @viking we all know how this will end, its just whether it will be quick or protracted!
TonaldDrump cheers @excel @tundra ill give it a bash
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Is 2018E The Trough? – In all candour, probably not. The company talked about 2019E being ‘challenging’ and backed away from the aspiration to maintain flat margins. This doesn’t necessarily mean either that revenues/margins will end up in decline but at this stage, as a bull, there is not a lot to hang on to. To the extent that the share price move discounts a 15% move in 2019E EPS (to 100p), it doesn’t immediately stand out as unreasonable.

Viking1 Battle of Magasin , bring your helmet
BE11:22am

Kantar, though. Selling Kantar would be good, right?

BE11:22am

From a balance sheet perspective, sure. Not so much from an earnings one.

Excel Developer @Tonald : investing.com is good but has no corporate bonds indices (unless I missed them). Watching credit spreads is a barometer of risk appetite.
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE11:22am

Such a sale would simplify the group and raise group net sales growth but
would have a potential negative eps impact. In 2017 Market Research net sales were £2.05bn with EBITA of £350m (margin 17.1%) equivalent to 16% of WPP sales and 15% of EBITA. We value it at £3.7bn (c9.6x 2018 EBITDA) based on comparator valuations (at a range of 8-10x).

BE11:23am

The sale of Market Research would (i) simplify the group, and (ii) remove a business that has undergrown the rest of WPP in net sales terms nearly every year for the last decade. Between 2014-16 WPP’s group net sales growth would have been on average 43bps a year higher without Market Research. However, if WPP sold the whole business at our £3.7bn valuation and retained the cash, it would take net debt/EBITDA down to just 0.42x but would dilute eps by c20% in 2019. If it returned all the cash in a share buyback, eps enhancement would be just c2% and net debt/EBITDA would rise to c2.4x. WPP would likely have to find a middle course.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Remember also that WPP recently lost the Ford creative account, and Ford was nearly definitely its biggest client.

cloudy @Tonald - Morningstar is okayish.
Blackbag99 What would it do for WPP debt pile BE?
BE11:25am

Let's say we rebase to 100p EPS for 2019 and you can still make a value argument. But you're also buying a turnaround story that's unlikely to show much in the way of a turnaround before 2020.

aldrin way JUST group spiked about 10% since 11am. Any rumours knocking around to explain it?
BE11:27am

By which time, who knows what advertising agencies will look like? Probably not much like they did, given the rapidly diminishing number of companies with which to place your ads.

Tax Realist no property was purchased when they bought Magasin, and they signed 25 year leases on all the premises....buyers may be reluctant on that basis

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Which ties back to Astra's externalisation revenue

BE11:32am

Alex Arfaei at BMO can explain.

BE11:33am

3Q18 Preview: It will likely be messy; however, excluding
externalization revenue, we expect a mostly in-line quarter. Our 3Q18 revenue and EPS forecasts are 5% and 32% lower than consensus, respectively, because of lower externalisation revenue and gross margin. Our forecasts for key products are mostly in line with consensus; however, we note that consensus Imfinzi numbers seem high. Nonetheless, product sales should grow ~3% y/y, which is positive. AZ has not announced any upfront payments for externalisation in 3Q18, whereas it had $1.05Bn in 3Q17. Moreover, ongoing externalization was ~$300MM in 3Q17, whereas we forecast ~$70MM in 3Q18. Therefore, we forecast ~$1.3Bn lower externalization revenue in 3Q18 y/y, and are $270MM below consensus, explaining the ~5% revenue differential. Excluding high-margin externalization revenue and Lynparza, we estimate gross margin was 76% in 3Q17; we forecast 78% in 3Q18, but this will be offset by higher payments to MRK for Lynparza. Consensus seems to be missing the positive impact of high-margin externalisation revenue and the negative impact of Lynparza on gross margin (3Q18 gross margin: Consensus 80%, BMO: 76%), thus amplifying the EPS differential vs. BMO. Overall, excluding the impact of externalisation revenue, our estimates are mostly in line with consensus. We believe the market will likely see past the externalisation revenue noise and focus on product sales and growth prospects from oncology and other late-stage assets.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

"But" management. Not "nut management" .... unfortunate typo. Here's Liberum.

BE11:39am

FY18 underlying PBT of £33m (pre-guided) is in line representing a 65% fall year-on-year. The new news is that no final dividend will be paid (consensus was 0.6p) and additional cost saving and capex reduction measures have been announced that management expects to release cumulative cash flow of c.£350m by FY20E. Returns on new format stores over peak will inform roll-out plans, there will be an update on the store programme in April and the strategic asset review is ongoing. The significant action we have been asking for has clearly been announced and we are encouraged by the more aggressive restructuring strategy to reposition the business. The release of £350m by FY20E, if delivered, could underpin the current valuation. There is a lot of detail to go through, but we are encouraged by today’s announcement and the potential for future cash flow improvement suggests a HOLD is now warranted after a share price fall of 75% YTD.

aldrin way thx monkey
BE11:40am

And Investec.

Grouchmonkey @BE no, right the first time, surely?
11:40 am
BE11:40am

Actions on capex and cost savings should relieve short-term cashflow pressures. To invest in Debenhams equity, you need to believe in an FY19 profit rebound and an industry backdrop kind enough for it to trade its way out of its current financial position, plus the disposal of Magasin du Nord. If all of that happens, we see material upside potential to the share price. We expect the share price to remain volatile, but on balance see some positive news in today’s statement. Our forecasts are under review; we previously forecast FY19e PBT of £42.8m versus consensus of £36m.

BE11:41am

And Stifel.

BE11:41am

Outlook: Reflecting significant uncertainty, the department store promotional environment and high operational gearing, Debenhams is not providing FY19 guidance.
Our estimates reflect an extrapolation of FY18's weak sales trends, further gross margin pressure (competitor clearance impacts) and some underlying cost inflation offset by the cost savings initiatives announced today. Our initial thoughts on estimates are that group PBT may fall to around break-even, entirely due to UK weakness. The group is still expected to generate net cash due to significant capex and dividend cuts.
Estimates and valuation: The lack of EPS and DPS caps the share price upside. EV/EBITDA is low at just c.3x with both Magasin du Nord and Debenhams International profitable at the EBIT level. FY19 fixed charge cover is 1.5x, and net debt/EBITDA 2.4x, expected to remain within covenants. The group is expected to be cash generative in FY19 and FY20. SOTP based Target Price falls to 8p but this will remain volatile along with earnings and EBITDA. Rating remains Hold.

11:43 am

I dunno. When management's been trying to rescue this thing for a decade yet the full-year exceptional charge is five times the market cap, I'm not seeing it as unalloyed good news.

An update on the BOE's consultation on equity release mortgages.

Tom Dalgleish Could the American bombs to democrats have caused the sudden selloff?
BE11:45am

The proposals included in this CP are:

(i) Firms using the approach and minimum calibration proposed would meet the PRA’s expectations for assessing the allowance for NNEG risk for the purposes of the EVT;

(ii) Firms holding ERMs should include an explicit allowance for ‘other risks’ within the EVT;

(iii) Where firms holding restructured ERMs in their MA portfolio cannot meet the EVT then this suggests that they may be taking an inappropriately large MA benefit. Accordingly, they will need to review their current approach and consider making changes to the structure, valuation or rating of restructured ERMs to ensure that they are able to calculate their MA benefit consistently with Solvency II requirements;

(iv) Firms holding ERMs that benefit from the TMTP should adopt the same approach to an assessment of NNEG and other risks for their ICAS TP calculations as they do for Solvency II TP calculations for the purposes of calculating TMTP to ensure consistency between the calculation bases; and

(v) Firms should consider whether they need to revise their internal models in response to any changes as above.

As in -- shut down TV (or not), spin off Openreach (or not) and ramping up mobile.

Here's Morgan Stanley.

Blank canvas thanks for everything today. much appreciated BE
BE12:00pm

On the plus side, Philip has led large complex businesses in the past and has technology experience at Worldpay. On the other hand, he lacks direct regulatory experience. Interestingly, Philip has committed to invest £2m in BT shares within 30 days of today's announcement.

Mouselet A lot of my friends seem to be taken in by the Initiative Q scam, though I hope all it will do is make their spam folder fuller
alewis2005 @Mouselet I've got a lot of messages about that too
12:01 pm

(Is that interesting? It feels a bit tawdry to me. The company basically just agrees to give him £2m providing he spends it on stock.)

TonaldDrump @BE competition in CityFibre to deal with too
Mouselet Surely there are more efficient ways for a company to cause its CEO to have some stock!
BE12:02pm

They also run the Openreach spinoff model using a multiple on its regulated asset base of 1-1.4x to reach a share price for BT of 260-310p versus 250p currently.

Tom Dalgleish @Mouse, we don't know where the 2 million is from
BE12:02pm

Macquarie gives him a checklist.

Seymour Flowes is this working?
Tom Dalgleish oops BE preempted me but my suspicions were correct
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

 Cut the dividend to remove the continuous headache and debate overs its sustainability. We target 10p for FY18/19.
 Push on 5G – EE grew because of 4G and it needs to be at the forefront of the next generation technology to avoid usurpation risk.
 Invest in IT (new single consumer, business IT stack with no split between OSS and BSS) and accelerate the move to IP (current 2025) to position BT for the Concierge economy.
 Push the convergent bundle – BT with EE could lead the push into selling technological neutral broadband.
 Commit to 10m FTTp homes – win over politicians with a 10m commitment. Openreach is currently delivering connections at less than £300 per home and BT Consumers’ and BT Enterprise can deliver sufficient demand to justify the roll-out.
 Avoid any further separation of Openreach. If there is a complete ownership separation the risks to OCF margins at BT’s retail business (BT Consumer at 15%) and Openreach needs BT to validate and cash flow its FTTp build.
 Listen to Matthew Key – perhaps even more interesting is Matthew Key’s appointment as Non-ED. He is ex O2UK and Telefónica and understands the value of “digital” and brands.

BE12:05pm

Seen quite a lot of comment on Matthew Key's appointment as noddy. Slightly odd to have the CEO appointment upstaged,.

Blackbag99 I can't see anyone paying that for Openreach; levered assets on cheap debt. Might as well buy the debt and steer clear of the equities.
BE12:06pm

I've no idea what "the concierge economy" is in that Macquarie note, BTW.

Excel Developer @BE: order stuff, have it delivered not to your home to a collection point?
12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

And instead of finding out, here's Barclays.

BE12:07pm

Although most recently from the Payments industry, Mr Jansen does have Telecom experience, having been group marketing director at Telewest (which later became Virgin Media). Prior to this he was at Procter & Gamble – ironically with outgoing BT Gavin Patterson (and also Jeremy Darroch and Allison Kirkby). An outsider in our view would be more likely to make significant changes to the balance sheet/dividend policy and company strategy, with our research indicating full separation of networks from retail operations would hinder the disruptive rollout of Alternative Fibre operators (although not in itself create value).

Mouselet I think the idea is that people will, instead of using Web sites, pay a Trusted Name handsomely to use the Web sites for them less competently. I do not believe this.
